data.text:
By Jagannath Roy

Country and Western music is now the rhythm of the young peoples’ hearts, not only of the West but also of the East. I always become nostalgic when I listen to country songs. The country is my love, passion, and inspiration for life. In a word, it is the only haven of my lone heart. I think it happens the same to you all. Well, I’d like to share some findings briefly here in this article on Country and Western music.

Though there are no specific definitions of Country and Western music, yet we can certainly define it as the synthesis of Country and Western music. Both are the genres of American popular music. For our convenience, we’ll term this genre sometimes by the title Country and Western to the rest of this article.

Origin And Development Of Country And Western Music

Country and western music is a folk genre that originated from American popular music. We can discover its roots from the Southeast and Southwest and West America. This music genre fused with the two regional styles — the Country and Western. Initially, there was a common difference between the two genres. Country music of the southeast used fewer instruments like guitar, fiddle, banjo, and harmonica, whereas the Western of the Southwest and West favored steel guitars and big bands whose style touched on rhythm. The lyrics of Country and Western music depict the emotions and experience of rural and urban poor whites. Sometimes they openly narrate the affairs of illicit love, crime, and prison life.

Country and Western is descended rightly from the folk songs, ballads, and popular songs that spread in America from the English, Scottish, and Irish settlers of the southeastern seaboard. Country and western has gained a nationwide audience from around the ’60s of the last century. To make a clear understanding of the Country and Western music, we should have a glance at the history of the Country and the Western music genre independently.

Country music was the music of working-class American and Afro-American working-class people who lived in the south, chiefly in the Appalachian Mountains. It began to gain national attention in the 1920s, blended with Appalachian folk and blues. The soulful ballad of country tunes played in upbeat at barn dances. The Appalachian folk, pejoratively called Hillbilly, originated from several European and African music genres like English ballads, Irish and Scottish traditional music, particularly fiddle music, hymns, and African-American blues, which had an impact on the development of Country music. Banjo, American fiddle, fretted dulcimer, and guitar used to perform Appalachian music. Fiddlin’ John Carson and Carter Family were the most famous of the Appalachian musicians.

Blues, a musical genre, came from the Afro-American people of North-America, that combined spirituals, work songs, field hollers, shouts, chants, and rhymed simple narrative ballads. It originated around the 1860s in the south of the U.S. Electric guitar, bass guitar, drums, piano, and harmonica used in blues. Bessie Smith (1894–1937), Blind Lemon Jefferson (1897–1929), and Charley Patton (1887–1934) were among the earliest blues singers of America.

Western music is a kind of country music that came from the Western part of the U.S and Western Canada. Several European folk music traditions and various cowboy songs had a direct impact on Western music. Western music depicts the life of North American cowboys and the working-class people of the highlands. This genre developed with English, Irish, Scottish folk ballads and, Mexican folk music. Tejano, a popular music style and the fusion of American, European, and Mexican folk music, also influenced western music.

The Country and Western music is the genre that came from Appalachian music and Western music in the mid of the 20th century by the music industry. Now, this genre amalgamated into the modern name Country music.

Christianity And Country Music

Most of the genres of Country and Western music propagandize secularism. Only the genre, gospel country music used to praise and worship Christ. Country singers perform country gospel in social and religious ceremonies used for motivating people with messages to lead a life morally in the right way. There are many organizations to promote Christian country singers, among them International Country Gospel Music Association (founded in 1957) plays a key role both in recording and spreading Christian country songs.

The famous radio personality Bob Wilson aired Christian country songs and Southern Gospel in his popular radio program — Gospel Country Round-up. The leading Country stars, The Louvin Brothers, the Carter Family, The Grand Ole Opry, and Faith Hill contributed largely to Christian Country music. Jesus Take the Wheel, I surrender, etc. are famous key tracks from Christian country music.

Country Music And Politics

Culturally, Country music was the form of expression of the working-class people of North America very before the first recording of Country music in the 1920s by the Carter Family or Jimmie Rodgers. Country music was the living narrative of blue-collar Americans. Later, the country singers and composers like Elvis Presley, Merle Haggard, Carrie Underwood, Bob Dylan, Brad Paisley, Country Rapper Cowboy Troy, and Joan Baez depict the contemporary sociopolitical phenomena with their country lyrics.

Music plays a role both in the anti-establishment and pro-establishment political movements. Country and Western music rightly do the same, composing and playing from the national anthem and patriotic songs to anti-war and anti-imperialist lyrics viz. the Beatles censored in the 1960s and 1970s. Pete Seeger’s songs like We Shall Overcome addressing the civil rights movement in America and Where Have All The Flowers Gone lifting a protest against the war and war politics Of the American State. Bob Dylan’s Blowin’ in the Wind against the Vietnam War, Carrie Underwood’s Love Wins, and Brad Praisley’s Wheelhouse are also groundbreaking lyrics representing the social and political reality of contemporary America and convey the messages to break the chains of confinement.

Some Well-known Country Stars And Entrepreneurs

First Generation (1920–1930)

Jimmie Rodgers (September 8, 1897 — May 26, 1933)

Jimmie Rodgers, an American singer-composer and musician is regarded widely as the father of Country music. He introduced Yodeling, a well-known form of singing in Country music. His best-known country lyrics like Blue Yodel, No Hard Times, Take Me Back Again, I’m Free From the Chain, My Time Ain’t Long, and Old Pal Of My Heart marks his prominence in country music. The Movie Honkytonk Man was based on his life. The music album The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers, A Tribute was compiled by Bob Dylan in 1997. The Blue Yeodeller (his nickname) died immaturely of tuberculosis in May 1933.

The Carter Family

The Carter Family was a folk music group in America. This family contributed widely to country music. Most of their songs recorded between 1927 and 1956.A.P Carter, his wife Sara Carter, and his sister-in-law Maybelle belong to this family. They influenced several popular music genres like bluegrass, Country, Southern Gospel, pop, and rock. They also influenced the U.S. folk revival of the 1960s. Their most famous country tracks are Keep On The Sunny Side, Wildwood Flower, Bury Me Under The Weeping Willow, Sailor Boy, When I’m Gone, and Single Girl, Married Girl.

Second Generation (1930–1940)

Roy Claxton Acuff (September 15, 1903 — November 23, 1992)

Roy Acuff, an American country singer and fiddler, was regarded as the King of Country Music. He was an internationally successful country singer. The Grand Ole Opry recognized him as one of the greatest musical figures in 1938. He was the first living inductee of the Country Music Hall of Fame. Roy Acuff’s best-known country tracks are Old Time Sunshine, Automobile of Life, Night Train to Memphis, Wabash Cannonball, and the Great Speckled Bird

Rubye Rose Blevins (30th Oct. 1908–3rd May 1996)

Rubye Rose, popularly known as Patsy Montana, was an American country music singer. She was the first female country singer. I Want to Be a Cowboy’s Sweetheart was her famous country track. She was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1996.

John Alexander Barfield (3 March 1909–16 January 1974)

John Barfield, an American old-time music and country performer, was best known for his song Boogie Woogie, the first country boogie. He was actually a street singer. Barfield’s song is considered the first country boogie. He died in 1974 at 64.

William Smith Monroe (13th Sept. 1911–9th Sept. 1996)

William Smith Monroe, popularly known as Bill Monroe was an American mandolinist, singer, and composer. He introduced the bluegrass music genre in country music. For this, he is regarded as the Father of Bluegrass. The name of his music band was the Blue Grass Boys. Monroe’s most famous songs are Blue Grass Breakdown, Wicked Path of Sin, My Rose of Old Kentucky, Little Cabin Home on the Hill, and Blue Moon of Kentucky.

Third Generation (1950–1960 )

John R. Cash (February 26, 1932 — September 12, 2003)

John R. Cash, popularly known as Jhonny Cash, was an American singer, composer, and actor. Most of his songs carried the themes of sorrow, moral affliction, and salvation. Folsom Prison Blues, I Walk the Line, Ring of Fire, Get Rhythm, and Man in Black are his most famous key tracks. Cash is the best-selling country artist of all time.

Henry John Deutschendorf Jr. (31st Dec., 1943–12th Oct., 1997)

Henry John Deutschendorf Jr., popularly known as John Denver, was an American singer, composer, and humanitarian. He was one of the most beloved singers of his age. Take Me Home, Country Roads, Thank God I’m a Country Boy and Sunshine on My Shoulders are his famous key tracks.

Patsy Cline (8th Sept. 1932–5th Mar. 1963)

Patsy Cline, an American singer, regarded as one of the most influential vocalists of the 20th century and one of the first country music artists who successfully pass over into pop music. You Made Me Love You (I Didn’t Want to Do It), Walkin’ After Midnight, I Love You So Much It Hurts, Leavin’ On Your Mind, Someday (You’ll Want Me to Want You) and Let the Teardrops Fall are her most famous country songs.

Fourth Generation (1970–1980)

Willie Hugh Nelson (born April 29, 1933)

Willie Hugh Nelson, an American musician, actor, and activist was one of the main figures of outlaw country which is a subgenre of country music. It grew in the late 1960s as a reaction to the conservative restrictions of the Nashville sound. Nelson has started his journey in music from his early childhood. His most famous country tracks are Pancho and Lefty, The Troublemaker, Whiskey River, Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain, Angel Flying Too Close to the Ground, On the Road Again, Crazy, Always on My Mind.

Bob Dylan (May 24, 1941)

Bob Dylan, an American singer, and composer is widely regarded as one of the greatest songwriters of all time. Blowin’ in the Wind (1963) and The Times They Are a-Changin(1964) are his famous tracks addressing the civil rights and anti-war movements. His lyrics stormed in American society. He is a well-known figure in country-rock.

Fifth Generation (1990–2000)

Alan Eugene Jackson (born October 17, 1958)

Alan Eugene Jackson is an American singer and composer. He is known best for mingling popular honky-tonk and mainstream country-pop. He is a member of The Grand Oly Opry and the Country music Hall of Fame. His most famous country tracks are Gone Country, Chasin’ That Neon Rainbow, Murder on Music Row, Midnight in Montgomery, Here in the Real World, Dallas.

Audrey Faith McGraw (born September 21, 1967)

Audrey Faith McGraw, popularly known as Faith Hill, is one of the American female country singers. Hill’s famous country albums are Take Me as I Am (1993) and It Matters to Me (1995). There You’ll Be brought her an international success.

Sixth Generation (2020 — Present )

Carrie Marie Underwood (born March 10, 1983)

Carrie Marie Underwood is an American country singer and composer. American Idol in 2005 brought her to prominence in country music. Inside Your Heaven, Jesus, Take the Wheel, and Before He Cheats became the best-selling singles in country music history. She was honored with the Grammy Awards several times for her music albums.

There is a long list of country stars. I only have shortlisted the names of country music figures who are most prominent from the generations.

Country Music And Way To Ahead

Country and Western music is a folk genre in America. We know that traditional folk or county music was the narrative of the working-class people of America. They would portray love, pain, sufferings, hopes, and dreams of their everyday life through their notes that were promise-bound always to the time. Modern musicians have adopted the country genres into their works. But we find distortions often in their performance. Despite this, country singers and composers played a great role in the 20th century. I’m Free From Chains, Blowin’ in the Wind (1963), The Times They Are a-Changin(1964), and Man in Black meaningfully represented the time and its interests.

The problem of unemployment was the burning issue of American society very before the covid-19 pandemic. The condition of the black people was worse than the whites both economically and socially in America. We stand before another great economic depression. People are suffering from insecurity. They have no dreams. They are also politically strayed. Now, it is the best time for country singers and composers to be the pathfinder for the people who are now in a stranded position socially, politically, and economically. They can motivate people with their country spirit. So, Country and Western music have more way to a go-ahead.
